title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the leafcutter ant's flight at the beginning of its life cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a new colony

options.label: B
options.text: To mate with males and store sperm

options.label: C
options.text: To forage for food

options.label: D
options.text: To defend against predators

options.label: A
options.text: Shelter and protection from predators

options.label: B
options.text: A source of water and minerals

options.label: C
options.text: Essential amino acids and digestive enzymes

options.label: D
options.text: Regulation of the colony's temperature

multiple-choice.question: What would likely happen to a leafcutter ant colony if it were to lose its fungal garden?

options.label: B
options.text: The ants would die off due to lack of nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: The ants would become more aggressive and competitive

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: The man who lost his sense of touch - Antonio Cataldo

options.label: B
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: C
options.text: Gastric flu

options.label: D
options.text: Proprioception disorder

options.label: B
options.text: Touch, pain, temperature, and proprioception

options.label: C
options.text: Smell, taste, touch, and pain

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: They are the same thickness and myelination

options.label: D
options.text: They are slower and unmyelinated

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty navigating the world

options.label: D
options.text: Increased sensitivity to light

options.label: B
options.text: Deafferentation

options.label: C
options.text: Somatosensory disorder

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The network would remain unchanged

options.label: D

title: How do airplanes actually fly? - Raymond Adkins

options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: B
options.text: Leonardo da Vinci

options.label: C
options.text: Isaac Newton

options.label: D
options.text: Galileo Galilei

options.text: Gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Lift

options.label: C
options.text: Drag

options.label: D
options.text: Thrust

multiple-choice.question: According to the debunked "Longer Path" or "Equal Transit Time" explanation, what is the reason for the creation of lift on an airplane wing?

options.label: A
options.text: The air molecules above the wing travel faster than those below due to a longer distance

options.label: B
options.text: The air molecules above the wing travel slower than those below

options.label: C
options.text: The air molecules above and below the wing travel at the same speed

options.label: D
options.text: The air molecules above and below the wing meet back up at the trailing edge

multiple-choice.question: As an airplane wing moves forward, what happens to the air above it?

options.label: A
options.text: It slows down and increases in pressure

options.label: B
options.text: It speeds up and decreases in pressure due to centripetal acceleration

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same speed and pressure

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes turbulent and detaches from the wing

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the pressure difference between the upper and lower surfaces of an airplane wing?

options.label: A
options.text: The wing produces drag

options.label: B
options.text: The wing produces thrust

options.label: C
options.text: The wing produces lift, allowing the plane to take off

options.label: D
options.text: The wing becomes unstable

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Bernoulli's principle

options.label: C
options.text: Euler's equations

options.label: D
options.text: Newton's laws

options.label: A
options.text: The air flows smoothly around the wing

options.label: B
options.text: The air bends around the wing, contributing to the pressure difference

options.label: C
options.text: The wing is curved upwards

options.label: D
options.text: The wing is angled downwards

multiple-choice.question: What is likely to happen if a wing is too curved or steeply angled?

options.label: A
options.text: The airflow above the wing will become faster and more efficient

options.label: B
options.text: The airflow above the wing will become slower and more turbulent

options.label: C
options.text: The airflow above the wing will detach and become turbulent, leading to instability

options.label: D
options.text: The wing will produce more lift

options.label: B
options.text: "The wing of doom"

options.label: C
options.text: "The curved wing"

options.label: D
options.text: "The flat wing"

options.label: D

title: What sex ed doesn’t tell you about your brain - Shannon Odell

multiple-choice.question: At what age range does puberty typically begin in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Between 5 and 8 years old

options.label: B
options.text: Between 9 and 14 years old

options.label: C
options.text: Between 15 and 18 years old

options.label: D
options.text: Between 19 and 22 years old

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of the hypothalamus in initiating puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce estrogen and testosterone

options.label: B
options.text: To release waves of a specialized hormone to trigger puberty

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the growth of reproductive organs

options.label: D
options.text: To control the development of the limbic system

multiple-choice.question: A 12-year-old student is experiencing mood swings and emotional changes. How might you explain these changes to them in simple terms?

options.label: A
options.text: "It's just a normal part of growing up, and you'll get used to it."

options.label: B
options.text: "Your brain is undergoing changes due to hormones, which can affect your emotions and behavior."

options.label: C
options.text: "You're just being dramatic and need to calm down."

options.label: D
options.text: "It's because you're not getting enough sleep."

multiple-choice.question: How do estrogen and testosterone affect neurons in the brain during puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: They destroy unnecessary neurons to make way for new ones.

options.label: B
options.text: They make neurons more or less excitable, alter their growth, or reshape their connections.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no direct impact on neurons.

options.label: D
options.text: They only affect neurons in the limbic system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the amygdala in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate emotions and detect threats in the environment

options.label: B
options.text: To control the development of the limbic system

options.label: C
options.text: To produce estrogen and testosterone

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the growth of reproductive organs

multiple-choice.question: Which brain region is associated with an increased response to rewarding activities during puberty, leading to a greater desire for exploration and social engagement?

options.label: A
options.text: Nucleus accumbens

options.label: B
options.text: Amygdala

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothalamus

options.label: D
options.text: Cortical regions

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about teenagers and decision-making?

options.label: A
options.text: They are incapable of making thoughtful decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only capable of making impulsive decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are more likely to make thoughtful decisions without adult supervision.

options.label: D
options.text: They are just as capable as adults of making thoughtful decisions when given time and space.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of the lengthy cortical development in adolescent brains?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for faster decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables adolescents to remain adaptable as they learn and grow in new situations.

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the risk of impulsive behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to earlier physical maturity.

multiple-choice.question: What factor, aside from hormones, may influence the development of the brain during adolescence?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetics

options.label: B
options.text: Nutrition

options.label: C
options.text: Experiences during adolescence

options.label: D
options.text: Socioeconomic status

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can an individual do to influence their development during puberty?

options.label: A
options.text: Focus solely on academic achievement.

options.label: B
options.text: Prioritize physical development over mental growth.

options.label: C
options.text: Make everyday choices, such as learning new skills, being a good friend, and setting boundaries.

options.label: D
options.text: Rely solely on hormones to guide their development.

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's reason for not telling his parents about his fractured foot when he was 12 years old?

options.label: A
options.text: He was afraid of going to the doctor.

options.label: B
options.text: He didn't want to miss the soccer movie.

options.label: C
options.text: He was worried about his parents' reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to avoid taking a break from soccer.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "illusion of continuity" that the speaker refers to in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our past and future selves are identical.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept that our memories remain unchanged over time.

options.label: C
options.text: The notion that our perspectives and views will remain the same in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: The understanding that our cells and biological makeup change constantly.

multiple-choice.question: What was Stephanie Rinka's initial request to her husband, John, regarding her end-of-life care if she were to develop a terminal illness?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to be kept on life support at all costs.

options.label: B
options.text: She preferred to die with dignity and not be put on a ventilator.

options.label: C
options.text: She asked John to make the decision for her.

options.label: D
options.text: She didn't discuss her wishes with John.

multiple-choice.question: What is the philosophical thought experiment known as the "ship of Theseus"?

options.label: A
options.text: A paradox about the nature of identity and change.

options.label: B
options.text: A puzzle about the morality of euthanasia.

options.label: C
options.text: A debate about the ethics of artificial intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: A discussion about the consequences of climate change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why our future selves might not share our current views and perspectives?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to external factors like social media and peer pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of internal changes in our brain and psychological makeup.

options.label: C
options.text: As a result of major life events and experiences.

options.label: D
options.text: Due to the influence of our family and upbringing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's first piece of advice on how to wrestle with the problem of the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: To stay curious and be open to new experiences.

options.label: B
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge the uncertainty of the future.

options.label: C
options.text: To be brave and take risks in life.

options.label: D
options.text: To resist change and hold onto one's current perspectives.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest we should approach making promises or commitments to others, considering the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: By assuming our future selves will have the same views and perspectives.

options.label: B
options.text: By taking into account the possibility that our future selves might disagree with our current decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: By avoiding making promises or commitments altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: By relying solely on our intuition and emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's second piece of advice on how to deal with the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more confident and assertive in our views.

options.label: B
options.text: To add a touch of humility to our expressions of opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid sharing our opinions on social media.

options.label: D
options.text: To seek validation from others for our views.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the potential consequences of not acknowledging the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: We might become more open-minded and adaptable.

options.label: B
options.text: We might make more informed decisions about our future.

options.label: C
options.text: We might experience resentment or bewilderment from our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: We might become more confident in our current perspectives.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's third piece of advice on how to deal with the "illusion of continuity"?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on our current limitations and weaknesses.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks, considering our future potential.

options.label: C
options.text: To prioritize short-term gains over long-term growth.

options.label: D
options.text: To rely solely on our past experiences and knowledge.

options.text: Pharaoh Khufu

options.text: 15 years

options.label: C
options.text: 20 years

options.label: D
options.text: 25 years

options.text: The area had an abundance of limestone and granite.

options.label: B
options.text: The plateau of bedrock provided a stable foundation.

options.label: C
options.text: The site was closer to the labor supply.

options.label: D
options.text: The area was considered sacred by the ancient Egyptians.

options.label: A
options.text: 10,000 workers

options.label: B
options.text: 20,000 workers

options.label: C
options.text: 25,000 workers

options.label: D
options.text: 50,000 workers

options.label: A
options.text: Every hour

options.label: B
options.text: Every 10 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Every 3 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: Every day

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Granite from a distant quarry

options.label: C
options.text: Limestone from a quarry approximately 13 kilometers away

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why did Hemiunu dispatch 500 workers in the project's first year to quarry granite?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: In Victorian England, what unusual method did some people use to manage their weight?

options.label: A
options.text: Consuming only juices for several weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Swallowing an unhatched tapeworm and letting it grow inside the body

options.label: C
options.text: Eating a very low-calorie diet

options.label: D
options.text: Exercising excessively

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it creates an energy deficit through a gradual decrease in calorie intake and an increase in regular exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: The body immediately starts burning fat cells as a major energy source

options.label: B
options.text: The body breaks down its emergency glucose supply, stored in the liver, and then starts burning fat cells

options.label: C
options.text: The body starts breaking down muscle mass for energy

options.label: D
options.text: The body's metabolism slows down

multiple-choice.question: What is likely to happen to a person's body if they drastically cut their calorie intake to lose weight?

options.label: A
options.text: Their body will steadily replenish its glycogen store and maintain muscle mass

options.label: B
options.text: Their body will go into a starvation response and break down its entire store of emergency glucose

options.label: C
options.text: Their body will not respond to the calorie reduction

options.label: D
options.text: Their body will immediately start burning fat cells as a major energy source

multiple-choice.question: Why are detoxification diets not suitable as a general cure-all for weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: They promote specific nutrients in high quantities

options.label: B
options.text: They restrict certain foods

options.label: C
options.text: They are too specific to address individual nutritional problems and may not provide essential nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: They are not based on scientific evidence

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it loses its glycogen store due to extreme calorie reduction?

options.label: A
options.text: The body loses fat mass

options.label: B
options.text: The body loses muscle mass

options.label: C
options.text: The body loses water weight

options.label: D
options.text: The body's metabolism increases

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential risk of going on a juice diet for several weeks?

options.label: A
options.text: The diet may not provide enough essential fats and proteins, compromising the immune system

options.label: B
options.text: The diet may provide too many essential fats and proteins

options.label: C
options.text: The diet may not be effective for weight loss

options.label: D
options.text: The diet may be too expensive

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a healthy dietary lifestyle for weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves extreme calorie reduction

options.label: B
options.text: It involves restricting certain food groups

options.label: C
options.text: It is sustainable, takes into account genetic and medical differences, and combines diet and exercise

options.label: D
options.text: It is based on a specific nutrient or food group

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential side effect of extreme diets that is often overlooked?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight gain

options.label: B
options.text: Nutrient deficiencies

options.label: C
options.text: Compromised immune system

options.label: D
options.text: Negative impact on mental health and overall well-being

multiple-choice.question: Why do many people feel pressured to diet for reasons other than health or happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to societal pressure to conform to certain beauty standards

options.label: B
options.text: Due to a desire to improve overall health

options.label: C
options.text: Due to a need to address a specific nutritional problem

options.label: D
options.text: Due to a lack of understanding about healthy weight loss

multiple-choice.question: What should people focus on instead of trying to lose weight quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding a quick fix for weight loss

options.label: B
options.text: Figuring out what the healthiest lifestyle is for themselves, including a balanced diet and regular exercise

options.label: C
options.text: Following a specific diet or exercise plan

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the importance of weight loss

title: The myth of Zeus' test - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: How did the villagers initially react when the two mysterious figures appeared and asked for food and shelter?

options.label: A
options.text: They welcomed the strangers with open arms and offered them food and shelter.

options.label: B
options.text: They were indifferent to the strangers' requests and ignored them.

options.label: C
options.text: They turned the strangers away, refusing to provide them with food and shelter.

options.label: D
options.text: They asked the strangers to prove their worth before providing help.

multiple-choice.question: What was notable about the relationship between Baucis and Philemon?

options.label: A
options.text: They were a young and influential couple in the village.

options.label: B
options.text: They were an elderly couple who were devoted to each other despite their poverty.

options.label: C
options.text: They were a couple who were estranged from each other and lived separate lives.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a couple who were known for their cruelty to strangers.

multiple-choice.question: How did Baucis and Philemon react when they realized that their guests were gods in disguise?

options.label: A
options.text: They panicked and tried to flee, fearing the gods' wrath.

options.label: B
options.text: They tried to impress the gods with their wealth and status, hoping to gain favor.

options.label: C
options.text: They apologized for not recognizing the gods earlier and offered more food and drink.

options.label: D
options.text: They were terrified, but still tried to show more hospitality and find a suitable offering.

multiple-choice.question: What significance did the goose hold in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of good luck and prosperity for Baucis and Philemon.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a source of food for Baucis and Philemon, which they were willing to share with the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a precious possession that Baucis and Philemon were willing to sacrifice to please the gods.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a reminder of their life before the gods' visit.

multiple-choice.question: What punishment did the villagers face for refusing to shelter the gods?

options.label: A
options.text: They were turned into animals as punishment for their cruelty.

options.label: B
options.text: They were cast underwater, and their village was transformed into a swamp.

options.label: C
options.text: They were forced to work in the temple as servants, atoning for their mistake.

options.label: D
options.text: They were forgiven and allowed to continue living in their village.

multiple-choice.question: What transformation occurred to Baucis and Philemon's cottage?

options.label: A
options.text: It was destroyed by the gods as punishment for the villagers' cruelty.

options.label: B
options.text: It was transformed into a grand temple for the gods, honoring Baucis and Philemon's kindness.

options.label: C
options.text: It remained unchanged, despite the gods' visit and the villagers' punishment.

options.label: D
options.text: It was sold to a wealthy merchant, who converted it into a lavish mansion.

multiple-choice.question: What concept did Baucis and Philemon demonstrate through their actions?

options.label: A
options.text: Xenophobia, or the fear of strangers and outsiders.

options.label: B
options.text: Philanthropy, or the love of wealth and material possessions.

options.label: C
options.text: Xenia, or the duty to care for and show hospitality to strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: Social status, or the importance of influence and wealth.

multiple-choice.question: How did Baucis and Philemon ultimately die?

options.label: A
options.text: They died of old age and illness, surrounded by their loved ones.

options.label: B
options.text: They were killed by the gods as punishment for their actions.

options.label: C
options.text: They were transformed into trees, remaining together forever.

options.label: D
options.text: They died in a natural disaster, such as a flood or earthquake.

multiple-choice.question: What significance did the intertwined branches of the linden and oak trees hold?

options.label: A
options.text: It symbolized the destructive power of the gods, warning others of their wrath.

options.label: B
options.text: It represented the enduring love and devotion of Baucis and Philemon.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a reminder of the importance of wealth and status in life.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a random occurrence with no deeper meaning or significance.

multiple-choice.question: What message does the story of Baucis and Philemon convey about hospitality and kindness to strangers?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is only important to show hospitality to those who are wealthy and influential.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a duty to care for and show kindness to all strangers, regardless of their status or identity.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a waste of time and resources to show hospitality to strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is only important to show hospitality to those who can repay us in some way.

title: The original ring of power - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: In Plato's "Republic," who recounts the story of the Ring of Gyges to argue that people can benefit by acting unjustly?

options.label: A
options.text: Socrates

options.label: B
options.text: Glaucon

options.label: C
options.text: Confucius

options.label: D
options.text: Plato

multiple-choice.question: According to Glaucon, why do people act justly?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a moral obligation

options.label: B
options.text: Because it brings them happiness

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a convention enforced through punishment and reward

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a natural human instinct

multiple-choice.question: If a person were to find a ring that makes them invisible, what action would Socrates consider the most just?

options.label: A
options.text: Using the ring to gain power and wealth

options.label: B
options.text: Using the ring to help others without being detected

options.label: C
options.text: Destroying the ring to avoid temptation

options.label: D
options.text: Not using the ring's power for personal gain

multiple-choice.question: Glaucon categorizes good things into three classes. Which class does he believe justice belongs to?

options.label: A
options.text: The first class, things desired for their own sake

options.label: B
options.text: The second class, things desired for their value

options.label: C
options.text: The third class, things desired for both their own sake and value

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to Socrates, what guides an individual to truth and knowledge?

options.label: A
options.text: Spirit

options.label: B
options.text: Appetite

options.label: C
options.text: Reason

options.label: D
options.text: Virtue

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between Socrates' and Glaucon's views on justice?

options.label: A
options.text: Socrates believes justice is a burden, while Glaucon believes it is a virtue

options.label: B
options.text: Socrates believes justice is a virtue, while Glaucon believes it is a burden

options.label: C
options.text: Socrates believes justice has intrinsic value, while Glaucon believes it is only valuable for its consequences

options.label: D
options.text: Socrates believes justice is a means to achieve happiness, while Glaucon believes it is a means to achieve power

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher argued that the state of nature is violent and selfish, and justice is imposed by authority?

options.label: A
options.text: Confucius

options.label: B
options.text: Thomas Hobbes

options.label: C
options.text: John Locke

options.label: D
options.text: Plato

multiple-choice.question: According to Socrates, what is the relationship between reason, spirit, and appetite in a just individual?

options.label: A
options.text: Reason is guided by spirit and appetite

options.label: B
options.text: Spirit is guided by reason and appetite

options.label: C
options.text: Appetite is guided by reason and spirit

options.label: D
options.text: Reason guides, spirit keeps appetite in check

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the story of the Ring of Gyges?

options.label: A
options.text: That power and wealth are the ultimate goals

options.label: B
options.text: That justice is a burden that brings rewards

options.label: C
options.text: That true happiness comes from acting justly

options.label: D
options.text: That people will act unjustly if given the opportunity to do so without consequences

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following best summarizes the philosophical debate presented in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether justice is intrinsic or extrinsic

options.label: B
options.text: Whether humans are naturally selfish or virtuous

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the state of nature is violent or peaceful

options.label: D
options.text: Whether justice has value in itself or only for its consequences

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the term "freelance" according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It was coined by Sir Walter Scott in his 1819 novel "Ivanhoe."

options.label: B
options.text: It was first used to describe mercenary soldiers in the 12th century.

options.label: C
options.text: It was popularized by Sir Walter Scott's use in his 1819 novel "Ivanhoe," but not coined by him.

options.label: D
options.text: It was first used in the 20th century to describe independent workers.

multiple-choice.question: According to a 2016 survey, what percentage of freelancers reported being happier than people in traditional jobs due to factors such as independence and flexibility?
What determines how much a freelancer can charge for their services, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of years of experience they have.

options.label: B
options.text: The demand for their skill and the number of people who have it.

options.label: C
options.text: The location where they work.

options.label: D
options.text: The type of industry they work in.

options.label: A
options.text: Only a skill that is in demand.

options.label: B
options.text: Only administrative skills such as project management and accounting.

options.label: C
options.text: A skill that is in demand and the ability to transform themselves into an entrepreneur.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of flexibility in work schedule.

options.label: C
options.text: The difficulty in determining exact earnings.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.text: $18 an hour

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: A single category of pay and benefits

options.label: B
options.text: Three categories of pay, benefits, and working conditions

options.label: C
options.text: Five categories

options.label: D
options.text: The transcript does not specify the exact criteria

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides a reliable living wage.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it offers benefits such as health insurance.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the easiest and fastest place to get hired for people who need to make money quickly.

options.label: A
options.text: How much do you value job security?

options.label: B
options.text: How much do you value flexibility or autonomy?

options.label: C
options.text: How much do you value working in an established structure?

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of benefits such as health insurance.

options.label: B
options.text: The difficulty in determining exact earnings.
